Open Thread 113.75

Posted on October 31, 2018 by Scott Alexander

This is the twice-weekly hidden open thread. Post about anything you want, ask random questions, whatever. You can also talk at the SSC subreddit or the SSC Discord server.

This entry was posted in Uncategorized and tagged open. Bookmark the permalink.
← Sort By Controversial
Working With Google Trends →

732 Responses to Open Thread 113.75

Reverse order
  1. johan_larson says:
    November 5, 2018 at 2:33 pm

    James Damore tweeted back in August that he had found a job.

    https://twitter.com/JamesADamore/status/1034623633174478849

  2. Telminha says:
    November 3, 2018 at 12:37 pm

    At this point in the thread I don’t know if anyone will see this, but I’ll try. I have two days off that I would like to use to learn more about libertarianism; I know very little. Besides Wiki, what are other good free resources on the subject? Are there any thinkers I should avoid? I read something about Rothbard and I didn’t like it. Thank you.

    • baconbits9 says:
      November 3, 2018 at 1:20 pm

      Are you more interested in economic, political or philosophical libertarianism?

      • Telminha says:
        November 3, 2018 at 2:08 pm

        I wish to have a general idea of what libertarianism means, enough so I can decide if I can call myself one (I’m currently a radical centrist), and also I want to impress a friend who believes I know nothing about politics and the economy, which is sadly true. If I have to choose, then I will say economic libertarianism.

        • Rebecca Friedman says:
          November 3, 2018 at 3:31 pm

          David Friedman is currently hosting a meetup, so he can’t respond, but his book The Machinery of Freedom is a good introduction to at least one, non-Rothbardian version, and the second edition is free online (look for that title here). He’s also got a lot of articles here, I don’t remember which, if any, assume background knowledge, and which make perfect sense before you’re familiar with libertarian ideas. Also I grew up with him so I might not be the best person to judge that. Have fun!

          • Telminha says:
            November 4, 2018 at 8:06 am

            Thank you, Rebecca!

        • Incurian says:
          November 4, 2018 at 9:07 am

          Arnold Kling is a libertarian economist who wrote “Specialization and Trade: A Re-introduction to Economics” which is both short and good.

        • baconbits9 says:
          November 4, 2018 at 11:09 am

          For part one Bob Murphy’s A politically correct guide to capitalism might suit you.

          For part 2 Mises’ Economic Calculation in the Socialist Commonwealth is probably your best shot.

    • toastengineer says:
      November 3, 2018 at 3:25 pm

      Libertarianism is fundamentally the idea that it should never be acceptable to hurt someone except to prevent/disincentive hurting someone. Most people will say “yeah, duh” to this, except our society accepts this all the time – for example, the government will haul you off and stick you in a concrete box just for cutting hair without a license, or having a drug they don’t approve of, or just refusing to fund their efforts to do all of this.

      Try asking the guys in /r/goldandblack, they’re specifically devoted to discussing hardcore libertarianism/anarchocapitalism. I haven’t been there in years but it was pretty great when I used to hang out there. Looks to be pretty good nowadays too.

      • Deiseach says:
        November 3, 2018 at 4:40 pm

        the government will haul you off and stick you in a concrete box just for cutting hair without a license, or having a drug they don’t approve of, or just refusing to fund their efforts to do all of this

        And this is what puts me off libertarianism – yes, the goverment will do this if you break the laws. Now, it’s certainly arguable that “refuse to get a license to cut hair, be warned, refuse to pay fines, be in contempt of court, be put in jail” is bad practice and a waste of time, but it is not the case that A Government Goon decides one Tuesday morning that he’s going to arrest all people wearing blue sweaters. There are laws and regulations, we’re not quite living in the society of “anyone with a pretension to being in office/the guy with a gun because he’s in the drug cartel that are the power in this area can take your money or imprison you just because they don’t like your face”.

        I have a feeling a libertarian state would have its own range of “don’t do that”, even if they decided not to call them laws or call themselves a government. For goodness’ sakes, any discussions of possible libertarian states founds themselves on the right to private property (and where do you derive that from, in a state of nature?), there will be courts to adjudicate disputes, contracts will be enforceable, and there will be private protection bodies to take the roles of police/army if needed. These states have just dressed up government functions in a different robe labelled “provided by private business and paid for by you directly, like taking out an insurance policy, instead of via your taxes”.

        • toastengineer says:
          November 3, 2018 at 5:50 pm

          I have a feeling a libertarian state would have its own range of “don’t do that”, even if they decided not to call them laws or call themselves a government.

          Yes! Exactly! Everything you’ve described is a feature, not a bug. Libertarianism does not pretend to be a total moral theory; it’s a theory of government, rules about what you may be physically hurt, imprisoned, or deprived of property for, not what you should be called nasty names for, socially shunned for, excommunicated for, banned from your local chinese buffet for, etc etc.

          I believe David Friedman even had a conception of “anarchocapitalist prisons” where basically if you’re such an asshole that literally no-one will let you on their property, you’d voluntarily check in to a sort of mental hospital where you’d have to agree to follow the rules and pay for your own rehabilitation. I don’t think it’d really work, but you see the sort of idea that is still considered in the purview of libertarianism. It’s very much NOT “no rules,” it’s “only point guns at people for breaking the really important rules.”

          There are laws and regulations, we’re not quite living in the society of “anyone with a pretension to being in office/the guy with a gun because he’s in the drug cartel that are the power in this area can take your money or imprison you just because they don’t like your face”.

          This is only partially true. The average American commits three felonies a day. If the government wants to put you away, they can. Luckily, most cops only decide they want to put you away if you’re really causing a problem, but if they do decide they want to put you away they can, whether or not you’ve done anything really wrong.

          So, in Libertaristan, the courts and laws work exactly like they do in most places, except there’s a really strong constitution saying, “no, you really can’t make things illegal JUST because you don’t like them, it has to verifiably hurt someone.”

          In Ancapistan the police and courts are similar, except the fact that they’re produced on the market means you get to pick (or you and your accuser have to agree on) one you like and trust. Think the police in your area are too violent? Tear up your contract with them and go to a rival.

          • John Schilling says:
            November 3, 2018 at 7:02 pm

            This is only partially true. The average American commits three felonies a day.

            That’s the title of a book, not a true statement of fact. The book that uses it as a title, nowhere defends it as a factual assertion, and we shouldn’t use it as such.

            That said, I’d guess it’s only off by two or three orders of magnitude, and you can do the math…

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 3, 2018 at 10:13 pm

            I believe David Friedman even had a conception of “anarchocapitalist prisons”

            That doesn’t sound like anything I remember having written.

          • Deiseach says:
            November 4, 2018 at 6:23 am

            rules about what you may be physically hurt, imprisoned, or deprived of property for, not what you should be called nasty names for, socially shunned for, excommunicated for, banned from your local chinese buffet for, etc etc.

            Then it’s disingenous to put the case against the systems of goverment we have now as “did you know they will lock you up in a box for perfectly innocent harmless actions?” If libertarians are not locking people up in boxes (and re-introducing some version of debtors’ prison sounds completely compatible with libertarianism and its fetish of private property), they will be engaging in social shunning – the “loss of repute” that is the punishment for people who break the sacred contracts they solemnly entered into.

            Libertarians will have their own set of laws; you may personally disagree with, say, the War on Drugs because you want to be free to take substances you decide you can handle. Why should someone else be bound by “don’t piss on my doorstep” rules because they don’t recognise any limits on “I needed to relieve myself and this is where I did it”? Yet I think even libertarians might have a rule about urination in public streets.

            And unless libertarians are going to be a whole new breed of human beings, there still will be “Johnny, don’t play with those kids, they’re not the right sort”, nasty names, and being barred from the local Chinese buffet going on even if nobody is living under the oppressive hoof of a state government.

            (The way contracts are spoken of, in what little I’ve read, does make it sound more akin to excommunication than anything else for violating or breaking them.)

          • Wrong Species says:
            November 4, 2018 at 7:45 am

            Every argument I’ve ever had with a libertarian:

            Them: The government is basically guys who threaten you with guns if you don’t follow their rules
            Me: And what exactly would happen in a libertarian world?
            Them: Libertarianism isn’t anarchy! The Legitimate Property Owner would threaten you with guns if you don’t follow his rules.

            And then it devolves in to a dispute about what counts as “legitimate”. The appeal of deontoligcal libertarianism is essentially a motte and bailey argument.

          • John Schilling says:
            November 4, 2018 at 1:46 pm

            Did none of them ever bother to point out that “Legitimate Property Owner” is not a singular term, but one that encompasses probably a billion or more individual property owners of largely unquestioned legitimacy and which can easily be expanded to include e.g. yourself? That is a rather significant difference from the small and exclusive club of “legitimate governments”, and if it’s really the case that none of the libertarians you have argued with have ever mentioned this, then you seem to have a unique ability to find the stupid ones.

            Also, most of the practical forms of libertarianism still include a great deal of common land(*) that is owned either by nobody at all or by a government that basically limits itself to only shooting at you if you shoot at other people.

            * And presumably the high seas, though that’s rarely mentioned explicitly.

          • albatross11 says:
            November 4, 2018 at 2:27 pm

            Yeah. Libertarianism has its problems, but its defining feature is that anything you do on your own property with other consenting adults must not be stopped by anyone else sending guys with guns. Smoke dope, have an orgy, get a sex change, form a suicide club, and even if I think you’re an idiot or a monster for doing those things, I can’t stop you. Even if the majority of your fellow citizens think that, we still can’t stop you.

            That contrasts with just about every other political philosophy around, where the state can and will send men with guns to stop you doing those things, perhaps after passing an explicit law against it with democratically elected representatives.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            November 4, 2018 at 8:57 pm

            Libertarianism has its problems, but its defining feature is that anything you do on your own property with other consenting adults must not be stopped by anyone else sending guys with guns.

            Yes, but how “must not” turns into “do not” is always shaky, in my mind. It seems to me to rely, at the bottom, not on principle, but on the will of the populace. How exactly you do have an actual police force, that serves everyone, to prevent anyone from impinging on your rights, without taxation?

            If you say that taxation is mandatory for that purpose, it seems to undermine the whole endeavor, IMO.

          • Aapje says:
            November 5, 2018 at 2:07 am

            One major problem with libertarianism is that it is based on the idea that externalities are a minor issue, while in reality many things we do have externalities and many laws/regulations are decisions which externalities to allow and which to limit or ban.

            So libertarians have problems explaining how their system works with very basic disputes, like a neighbor making noise and me disliking it. Is the noise something I must accept, because the noise is made on the property of the neighbor? Does this mean I have to accept him making enormous noise at night? Or is the noise harm to me and can I make him stop (using the men with the guns)? However, in that case, can I stop him talking in his house, because even that creates detectable noises in my house?

          • 10240 says:
            November 5, 2018 at 3:39 am

            @Aajpe The usual solution is that when a condominium is built, the developer would make a contract with the buyers which sets certain rules (and possibly even that rules can be changed through a democratic process), and also requires owners to only sell to buyers who then sign the same contract. In his nodrumia post, Scott outlines the significant differences between such voluntary communities and countries in the present form, with regards to exit rights etc. (Though, unlike Scott, I think that the fact that existing towns didn’t came into being through such contracts is an important difference from voluntary communities, even if towns are better than countries with regards to exit rights.)

            It’s a difficult question how to handle existing properties, if we were to transition to a libertarian world. My solution would be to grandfather in some existing regulations as though they were contracts, with the justification that someone who has bought property in the present non-libertarian world was aware that regulations existed.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            November 5, 2018 at 4:37 am

            a neighbor making noise and me disliking it

            This is looking at it backwards, IMO.

            My neighbor comes over with his hired guns and tells me to stop making noise on my property. What is my recourse? It’s all very good to say “it’s not allowed” but you have to have a means of making it “not allowed”. And that system has to be workable for and responsive to a large, dense population.

            That all takes resources, and those resources need to be extracted from somewhere.

          • John Schilling says:
            November 5, 2018 at 7:11 am

            My neighbor comes over with his hired guns and tells me to stop making noise on my property. What is my recourse? It’s all very good to say “it’s not allowed” but you have to have a means of making it “not allowed”.

            As I believe has been explained here many times before, for the vast majority of libertarians who are not also anarcho-capitalists, your recourse is to call the police and have them arrest the gun-toting tresspassers and this is expected to work faster, better, and cheaper in a world where those police aren’t spending most of their time e.g. trying to enforce drug prohibition.

            The minority of libertarians who are also anarcho-capitalists, A: don’t get to speak for libertarians in general and B: will tell you how your recourse is a private protection agency that should look an awful lot like a police department from the end-user perspective. And we’ve got the guy who literally wrote the book on that right here if you have trouble with the concept. But even if, like myself, you aren’t entirely convinced on that front, that still leaves you with the whole range of political theories / social organizing principles that aren’t specifically anarcho-capitalist libertarianism.

          • baconbits9 says:
            November 5, 2018 at 7:18 am

            One major problem with libertarianism is that it is based on the idea that externalities are a minor issue, while in reality many things we do have externalities and many laws/regulations are decisions which externalities to allow and which to limit or ban.

            This is generically false, economic and political libertarianism is heavily grounded in the concept that governments create externalities which are difficult to resolve. The fact that libertarians consider conflicts over appropriate noise levels to be minor and locally solvable issues compared to the waging of war and the draft shows how poorly thought out this criticism is.

          • albatross11 says:
            November 5, 2018 at 10:25 am

            Libertarians think there should be a government, just a smaller and less intrusive one. That implies taxes of some kind, though I don’t think there’s any clear consensus on what taxes or how much. The usual idea I’ve seen from libertarians is that the cops, courts, and military are necessary parts of the government, but that many other parts should probably be moved to the private sector, abolished, or (for people who also like federalism) moved to a more local level of government.

            So we have a set of laws, and police and courts and jails to enforce them. Libertarian ideas help us figure out which laws we ought to have–laws about crimes with nonconsenting or unable-to-consent victims make sense. Laws to protect adults from their own decisions, no.

            Externalities are an issue. The best discussion of how to deal with externalities as a practical matter that I know is David Friedman’s excellent book _Law’s Order_. A short version of what I got from the book is that there’s not a single best way to handle externalities–it depends on a lot of details like who can avoid them and how expensive it is to detect them. I think a more libertarian version of US society can handle these pretty well.

            One problem with worrying too much about externalities is that it’s always possible to spin up some kind of justification for anything you want to do on the basis of claimed externalities. Everything from shutting down opposition newspapers to suppressing unpopular religions to forcibly “treating” gays to turn them straight can be (and has been) done with this kind of justification.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            November 5, 2018 at 10:37 am

            @albatross11:

            But then one of the most common rallying cries of Libertarians, “Taxation is theft”, falls. And failure to pay taxes becomes a violation of the NAP. An if failure to pay taxes in a violation of the NAP…

            or, you have to justify punishment for failure to pay taxes in some way other than NAP, and that also creates large ideological structural issues, in terms of objecting to other ideologies.

          • Mr. Doolittle says:
            November 5, 2018 at 12:49 pm

            @HeelBearCub

            But then one of the most common rallying cries of Libertarians, “Taxation is theft”, falls. And failure to pay taxes becomes a violation of the NAP. An if failure to pay taxes in a violation of the NAP…

            or, you have to justify punishment for failure to pay taxes in some way other than NAP, and that also creates large ideological structural issues, in terms of objecting to other ideologies.

            If taxes are voluntary associations, then they are not theft. In fact, if you choose to select a service and fail to pay, you are indeed violating the NAP.

            The stronger Libertarian approaches tend to involve a group of people deciding to do things like a police force (with or without that name). I’ve seen the argument that Libertarians are just renaming our current system, but the key difference in the voluntary part. If you have no choice but to pay your taxes, then it’s “theft.” If you choose to partake of services, then you cannot refuse to pay.

          • Aapje says:
            November 5, 2018 at 1:24 pm

            @10240

            The usual solution is that when a condominium is built, the developer would make a contract with the buyers which sets certain rules

            Some people own their house & property. Even if we would force everyone to rent, that just kicks the problem up to the renters, as you will have two property owners near each other who can have disputes at one point. What happens if someone decides to build his noisy airport* near my condominium and my tenants get angry?

            Of course, we can kick this problem up another level by making entire cities/towns owned by the same entity. Of course, as libertarians, we cannot enforce that people leave a no man’s land. Besides, cities tend to expand, swallowing up towns. Oops. So we probably need to go up another level and give regulatory authority to some level that is above the town/city level. Let’s call it the state government. Or alternatively we could take your communist libertarian solution of centralizing land ownership to solve problems and make all land owned by the state.

            Anyway, once you have these restrictive contracts, what is the advantage over the government? I’d rather be subject to regulations that I can influence with my vote than to be forced to sign contracts to have a roof over my head, where any mistake in not understanding the contract can doom me. We already know that most people don’t read EULAs.

            * Airport noise is a major issue in many places and many airports take extensive measures to reduce noise levels. How does one force airports to do this under libertarianism?

            @baconbits9

            The fact that libertarians consider conflicts over appropriate noise levels to be minor and locally solvable issues compared to the waging of war and the draft shows how poorly thought out this criticism is.

            A dispute over noise levels of Amsterdam Airport is one of the major recurring disputes in my country, as various important desires clash spectacularly, with no obvious win-win solution. An extremely major issue in my country right now is the earthquakes caused by gas extraction. Externalities are not some minor issues that only happen between neighbors. They scale up to national and even international level.

            At the international level, we do lack international democracy and shared international culture, which makes it much harder to solve international externalities, which sometimes results in war (although this is not the only reason for war). However, to paint this as a failure of a strong centralized government is absurd, because it results from the lack of it*.

            The idea that your ideology will magically resolve conflicts between peoples, so they no longer desire war, seems like wishful thinking at best.

            * Not that a strong international government can really work, due to the cultural differences. It’s also undesirable for other reasons.

            @albatross11

            A short version of what I got from the book is that there’s not a single best way to handle externalities–it depends on a lot of details like who can avoid them and how expensive it is to detect them.

            Yep and that’s why an ideologically pure solution cannot work and a democratic government is crucial to pick the right tool for the job. Regulation can be that right tool.

          • albatross11 says:
            November 5, 2018 at 2:04 pm

            There are a whole bunch of different shades of libertarian. Some basically want the current US society, but moved substantially in a libertarian direction–you still have taxes but they’re lower and less intrusively collected, you still have cops but they don’t have as many laws to enforce, etc. (That’s pretty close to where I am.)

            There are also libertarians who want to arrange society by the non-aggression principle. Personally, I think that’s unworkable in practice, in much the same way I think it’s unworkable in practice to have the country become completely pacifistic. And yet, I think we could move far in the direction of fewer violations of the NAP and fewer aggressive foreign policy moves, before we started losing more than we gained.

            Somehow, we start out talking about how to fund our government and agree that we need taxes to fund a military so we don’t get taken over by the neighbors, and a police force so we don’t get taken over by gangs. And then somehow we find ourselves paying taxes so farmers can be paid not to grow crops, or so we can send foreign aid to some kleptocrat to buy his friendship for a few years.

          • Skivverus says:
            November 5, 2018 at 2:06 pm

            Anyway, once you have these restrictive contracts, what is the advantage over the government? I’d rather be subject to regulations that I can influence with my vote than to be forced to sign contracts to have a roof over my head, where any mistake in not understanding the contract can doom me. We already know that most people don’t read EULAs.

            Most people don’t read laws, either, and the consequences for not following those are generally accepted to be more severe than “you can no longer use our services”.

          • baconbits9 says:
            November 5, 2018 at 2:32 pm

            A dispute over noise levels of Amsterdam Airport is one of the major recurring disputes in my country, as various important desires clash spectacularly, with no obvious win-win solution. An extremely major issue in my country right now is the earthquakes caused by gas extraction. Externalities are not some minor issues that only happen between neighbors. They scale up to national and even international level.

            You missed the point entirely. Wars, and specifically wars that include conscription, produce enormous externalites. Large governments cause these externalities and they dwarf the ones that they are able to competently solve. Citing issues your government also has not been able to solve isn’t a strike against libertarian thought, and citing what actually are trifling issues in terms of costs when compared to war (just one example of government caused externalities) is doubly missing the point.

            However, to paint this as a failure of a strong centralized government is absurd, because it results from the lack of it*.

            Ah yes, WW1 and WW2, massive wars fought by countries with weak governments.

            The idea that your ideology will magically resolve conflicts between peoples, so they no longer desire war, seems like wishful thinking at best.

            You made an obviously false claim that libertarians don’t take externalities seriously, this response is filled with obvious attempts at avoiding admitting to that mistake with cheap insults.

          • Aapje says:
            November 5, 2018 at 2:57 pm

            @albatross11

            There are a whole bunch of different shades of libertarian. Some basically want the current US society, but moved substantially in a libertarian direction–you still have taxes but they’re lower and less intrusively collected, you still have cops but they don’t have as many laws to enforce, etc. (That’s pretty close to where I am.)

            In the old world, we just that ‘liberal.’

            Social democrats set themselves apart from communists by using a different name and not using the generic ‘socialist’ as much, so others would understand better what policies they advocated, based on their label. Libertarianism may try the same, because y’alls PR is poor.

            @Skivverus

            With laws you at least have a single set of them, as well as semi-reliable examples and jurisprudence.

            It gets a lot more complicated when individuals get to make their law to a large extent. It’s not uncommon for new laws to require interpretation by the courts, which then sometimes results in unexpected outcomes and even requires repairs by congress. Fortunately, most laws are old.

            Not so if individuals get to make the law. There will be a lot of uncertainty and different interpretations.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            November 5, 2018 at 3:01 pm

            If taxes are voluntary associations, then they are not theft.

            That just loops back around to “You paid your guys with guns to hassle me about my noise and and I have no recourse because I can’t afford guys with guns”.

            This then leads to the fact that non universal police forces do not scale with any sort of population density, and the end result is just being forced to pay the mob for “security”. There is no guarantee in a non-universal system that the NAP will be upheld.

          • Aapje says:
            November 5, 2018 at 3:20 pm

            @baconbits9

            It wasn’t intended as a cheap insult, I just fail to see how ancap libertarianism will somehow prevent war. I guess I can see it if it is implemented so poorly that it causes society to fall apart in such a way that it becomes a low level permanent conflict that never rises to a level that counts as civil war, but just counts as an ultra-violent society.

            However, if we are talking about a libertarian state that is able to coordinate large scale projects, then why can that project not be war? The draft is hardly necessary for war. The UK only had the draft from 1916 to 1920 & 1939 to 1960, yet it managed to fight many wars outside of those periods, including two bloody years of WW I.

            It’s not like you need a central government to have an army. Both 1930’s Germany and Ancient Rome saw private militias that fought each other.

            Under ancap libertarianism, it seems very tempting for rich people to pay for a private army, rather than help pay for a generic army, because the private army is more useful to them specifically (for their personal ‘defense,’ of course, although the best defense is offense as they say).

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 5, 2018 at 9:04 pm

            Libertarians think there should be a government, just a smaller and less intrusive one. That implies taxes of some kind

            Neither statement is true of all libertarians, although both are probably true of a majority of self-identified libertarians and a large majority of libertarians in the weaker sense.

            Some libertarians are anarchists. And some minarchists, most notably Ayn Rand (who didn’t consider herself a libertarian but was mistaken), wanted a government that supported itself without taxes on the basis of a fee for services, such as a registration charge for contracts that the government would enforce.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 5, 2018 at 9:07 pm

            Yep and that’s why an ideologically pure solution cannot work and a democratic government is crucial to pick the right tool for the job.

            That assumes that a democratic government is the right tool for picking tools. Given the number of activities where governments perform worse than private organizations, it isn’t obvious that the production of law is one where they perform better.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 5, 2018 at 9:10 pm

            In the old world, we just that ‘liberal.’
            …Libertarianism may try the same, because y’alls PR is poor.

            You are missing the relevant history. The position libertarians now hold used to be called liberalism. Then the opponents of liberalism stole its name to be used for democratic socialism in dilute acqueous solution. We eventually gave up on getting it back so we stole “libertarian” from the believers in free will and the left anarchists.

          • Aapje says:
            November 5, 2018 at 11:31 pm

            @DavidFriedman

            That assumes that a democratic government is the right tool for picking tools. Given the number of activities where governments perform worse than private organizations, it isn’t obvious that the production of law is one where they perform better.

            Part of the reason that you are a libertarian in the first place is because you define ‘perform worse’ differently from many if not most other people*. So of course you believe that many things would be better if the private sector ran it. However, balancing the upsides with the downsides in a way that you prefer doesn’t necessarily match the balance that others prefer.

            Ultimately, most people prefer 1 man, 1 vote over 1 dollar, one vote. So at the end of the day, one has to convince citizens based on their standards, not yours.

            BTW. The US government is fairly incompetent among first world nations. The solution to that is not necessarily to privatize things, but may be to do government better.

            We eventually gave up on getting it back so we stole “libertarian” from the believers in free will and the left anarchists.

            Two wrongs don’t make a right.

            * Perhaps also because you are particularly suited to libertarianism, being both well educated and moneyed. A system where you personally benefit more from its features than others, will tend to get the benefit of personal bias.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            November 6, 2018 at 4:23 am

            Two wrongs don’t make a right.

            I think Libertarianism is a mess on almost all fronts, but this is unkind.

            Language changes over time. This is inevitable and merely needs to be taken into account. It isn’t wrong.

            And when we are talking politics, ideologies and named coalitions drift over time as well. That is also simply inevitable.

          • Paul Brinkley says:
            November 6, 2018 at 8:35 am

            @HeelBearCub

            [Voluntary taxation] just loops back around to “You paid your guys with guns to hassle me about my noise and and I have no recourse because I can’t afford guys with guns”.

            Hmm. I’m worried that I’m missing your point here. Are you saying one party threatens the other with guns if they don’t pay taxes, the latter responds by grudgingly paying taxes, the former declares that it’s not theft? Because that would seem to make the “taxation is theft!” argument in a very textbooky way, so that can’t be what you meant. But your argument seems to have been initially a response to something albatross11 said, and I’m having trouble picking out what, exactly.

            Maybe it’s albatross11’s general description of libertarians as being willing to give in on a 100% pure interpretation of NAP? Because that’s exactly how I read his post: some libertarians are willing to compromise. The ones who commit to purity tend to become ancaps. And the more seasoned ancaps appear to have thought farther on this and concluded that some aggression is going to be inevitable, and discuss ways to address it, such as rights enforcement agencies.

            And yes, if some libertarians are minarchists, then they favor taxing for certain services, which means they give a bit on NAP. The conclusion I draw from this is not that they’re hypocrites, any more than I think Democrats are hypocrites if they give a little on gun control or environmentalism in return for welfare programs, for example.

            It also means that I think “taxation is theft!” isn’t really that central a rallying cry to libertarians. It may appear so, given how glib and concise it is, but so does stuff like “healthcare is a basic right!” or “cold, dead hands!”.

            There is no guarantee in a non-universal system that the NAP will be upheld.

            Yeah, sure, I agree with that. But only because there are no guarantees that any social system’s fundamental tenets will be upheld. There’s no guarantee in a fascism that people will work to the betterment of the body public. There’s no guarantee that politicians will serve their constituents’ interests in a representative democracy. There’s no guarantee that a Fabian socialism’s leaders will make the best macroeconomic decisions.

            To me, the idea to keep in mind is how well those core tenets will bolster that society against people who forget the non-core tenets, and people who choose to defect against the core. But I don’t know how many other libertarians think in that way. Also, I don’t consider myself a libertarian, except contingently.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 6, 2018 at 12:57 pm

            Part of the reason that you are a libertarian in the first place is because you define ‘perform worse’ differently from many if not most other people

            You are mistaken. My basic argument for libertarianism, and for that matter for anarcho-capitalism, is that it produces better outcomes by widely shared standards–healthier, happier, richer people.

            Neither one man one vote nor one dollar one vote is an outcome. Both are tools.

          • Wrong Species says:
            November 6, 2018 at 8:17 pm

            I’d rather be subject to regulations that I can influence with my vote than to be forced to sign contracts to have a roof over my head, where any mistake in not understanding the contract can doom me.

            Exactly. Especially if you’re a poor person in ancapistan, your living situation is far worse than anything right now, even assuming that it doesn’t immediately blow up in to violent conflict.

          • Aapje says:
            November 7, 2018 at 5:36 am

            @HeelBearCub

            How am I unkind? Friedman argued that classic liberals stole the term ‘libertarian’ from people with different beliefs.

            His word choice implies that this ‘stealing’ involved doing a wrong and he may have implied that they felt justified in doing so because their own label was ‘stolen.’

            Two wrongs don’t make a right seems like a perfectly suitable comment for a situation where those who are harmed respond by doing harm.

            @DavidFriedman

            My basic argument for libertarianism, and for that matter for anarcho-capitalism, is that it produces better outcomes by widely shared standards–healthier, happier, richer people.

            Many and probably most people value things like equality, (cosmic) justice, etc. These are inconsistent with your standards. Libertarianism increases inequality to an extent that most people consider unfair and allows for behaviors that most people consider unjust.

            Ultimately, the outcome that normal people tend to see as their ideal is unachievable, because their desires exceed what the laws of physics and human nature allow. So we need to pick our poison. I don’t see how a system without a decent amount of society-wide control can result in the outcome that the average person prefers, especially since many people have preferences for society-wide outcomes and for their own behaviors that are in conflict, so if they act selfishly, they get undesired society-wide outcomes.

            Libertarianism is inherently about prioritizing personal choice over society-wide choices, but many people don’t want that.

          • Paul Brinkley says:
            November 8, 2018 at 7:06 am

            Many and probably most people value things like equality, (cosmic) justice, etc. These are inconsistent with your standards. Libertarianism increases inequality to an extent that most people consider unfair and allows for behaviors that most people consider unjust.

            I think this is true. But at the same time, I wonder if people prefer everyone equal, but at a subsistence level of survival, or unequal (to some negotiable extent), but with the median level being that of US middle class, say.

            There’s also the issue where libertarians appear to disagree with American liberals about whether it’s possible to have both middle class median survival and cosmic justice everyone would consider acceptable.

            This might be a useful thing to discuss in OT 114.25, once it’s spun up. These are relatively basic questions, though, by SSC standards; I just don’t know when or if they’d been brought up before.

          • IrishDude says:
            November 8, 2018 at 1:49 pm

            @Aapje

            Many and probably most people value things like equality, (cosmic) justice, etc. These are inconsistent with your standards. Libertarianism increases inequality to an extent that most people consider unfair and allows for behaviors that most people consider unjust.

            Equality is perfectly compatible with libertarianism, if that’s what people want and prioritize. I just listened to an interesting EconTalk episode on kibbutzim, communal settlements in Israel that practice equal sharing. These communities of equality can exist under libertarianism, as long as people voluntarily join them. Here’s an interesting snip from the podcast:

            Russ Roberts: But we should also mention that, starting in the 1980s and 1990s, some of the more radical pieces of the kibbutz started to unravel. The first being the one you mentioned–children were no longer kept apart from their parents. But, then–I would say most, if I read your book correctly, of the kibbutzim have gotten rid of complete egalitarianism on income. And now they are smaller, and they’ve had trouble getting the second and third and fourth generations to stay on. You know: ‘After they’ve seen Paree [Paris], how do you keep ’em down on the farm?’ is the expression. And that’s been the challenge for the kibbutz movement in Israel.

            Ran Abramitzky: Yes. That’s right. So, starting in the 1990s, many kibbutzim for the first time in their history started to shift away from equal sharing. Some kibbutzim only had minor deviations from the equal sharing models, but many have moved to market forces and now earnings, income, is based on people’s earnings. Only 20% of kibbutzim maintain the egalitarian model. And so, that’s right. It followed–I’m not sure if you want me to talk more about how it came about, but that’s basically right, what you are saying. They did shift away from equal sharing, recently.

            Kibbutz had difficulties with 2nd and 3rd generation children choosing to stay in the egalitarian social situation compared to the alternatives. Their size shrunk over time and a large majority of the remaining kibbutz went to unequal sharing. Equality comes with a cost, a price that most aren’t willing to pay.

            Still, it works for some and for those who like that lifestyle, they can choose it under a libertarian framework. And, for those who are okay with some level of inequality but want things more equal, they’d be free to set up communities that reflect the amount of inequality they prefer.

            I’d be interested in seeing how people vote with their feet, when given the option of, at the extreme, people keeping everything they earn, and at the other extreme, a complete flattening of income through income redistribution. I suspect that most people would lean more towards living in the former society rather than the latter, but also that a fair amount of people would choose to live in something less than everyone keeping exactly what they earn.

            His word choice implies that this ‘stealing’ involved doing a wrong and he may have implied that they felt justified in doing so because their own label was ‘stolen.’

            I took his comments as tongue in cheek.

            EDIT: Just wanted to add an acknowledgement that most people like families that function close to “from each according to their ability, to each according to their needs”, including me, but I think the desire for equal sharing above the family level is pretty rare, especially when strangers are involved.

        • albatross11 says:
          November 4, 2018 at 5:48 am

          So, the question in any political philosophy is about what the laws should be, right? I mean, if someone passes a law to say that anyone caught reading the wrong book gets shot at dawn, that’s still just enforcing the law, but probably most of us can agree that it’s a pretty oppressive law that would be a bad idea for our own country to adopt.

          Libertarianism as a political philosophy is basically about what principles we should use to decide what laws we ought to have, and what laws we ought not to have.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 5, 2018 at 9:11 pm

            So, the question in any political philosophy is about what the laws should be, right?

            That’s one question. A different and arguably deeper question is what the institutions should be that generate the laws.

          • albatross11 says:
            November 6, 2018 at 6:06 am

            Yeah, there’s this book I’ve been meaning to read that talks about legal systems very different from our own. I ought to get on that….

        • DavidFriedman says:
          November 4, 2018 at 10:24 am

          Every argument I’ve ever had with a libertarian:…
          The appeal of deontoligcal libertarianism is …

          It appears to follow that you have only argued with deontological libertarians. That’s not the only kind that exists.

          • Wrong Species says:
            November 4, 2018 at 1:38 pm

            I’m aware. I usually don’t argue with consequentialists because far more difficult to argue about in one conversation and involves a lot of empirical research that I don’t have.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            November 4, 2018 at 3:05 pm

            Consequentialist arguments can be empirical, but they don’t have to be–one can offer theoretical reasons to believe that one set of institutions will have better consequences than another.

            It sounds from what you posted as though you are not a libertarian. So you have presumably concluded that some other set of institutions has better consequences–unless you are working from some alternative deontological basis.

            You are not prepared to look at the relevant empirical evidence. It seems to follow that you have concluded, on theoretical grounds, that libertarianism would work poorly. In which case you should be open to arguments based on theoretical grounds that it would work well.

            Am I missing something?

          • Wrong Species says:
            November 4, 2018 at 5:08 pm

            I’ve looked at libertarian consequential arguments and I find them lacking. I just don’t have enough knowledge to convince someone else that libertarian consequentialism is wrong.

          • baconbits9 says:
            November 4, 2018 at 7:06 pm

            All consequentialist outcomes are lacking on a large scale (even on an individual level I would argue). There is no end to the possibilities of tweaking timelines, assumptions and interpretations to prove that your preferred world view is better/best. If you hunt down a consequentialist communist you will eventually hear that a true revolution will be so glorious that it will justify all previous failed attempts.

            Or as SMBC put it

            Number of lives saved by Batman = X
            Number of lives save by the guy who shot Bruce Wayne’s parents = X-2

        • 10240 says:
          November 4, 2018 at 5:40 pm

          My deontological justification for libertarianism is the following: if it’s legal a person (or a set of persons) to take an action A, and they voluntarily take another action B that doesn’t leave anyone worse off than A (except perhaps some in this set of people who voluntarily chose B), then B should be legal too. Property rights have a similar justification: if you have the right to not create an object, you should also have the right to create it and decide who can use it and how, as long as this makes no one (except perhaps you) worse off than if you don’t create the object. And, as a base case, it should be legal to not exist (or to exist but not interact with anyone).

          These principles have far-reaching consequences, but they also seem very basic freedoms to me: don’t punish someone who doesn’t hurt anyone, don’t punish Pareto improvements. They are pretty similar in effect to the NAP, only giving a different judgement perhaps on some edge cases. I prefer them to the NAP because I find them more convincing (sort of consequential, though not utilitarian) arguments; because they don’t resort to defining trespass or theft as aggression (which many find arbitrary, including me), and because I don’t think the most fundamental principle should be a prohibition (as opposed to a right or a freedom; prohibitions are instrumental values to secure rights or freedoms).

          DavidFriedman, are there prominent libertarians who use similar arguments? (In a deontological way; in economics, I’m sure that similar arguments about Pareto improvements show that free markets maximize utility in many cases, but not always.) Is there a catchy handle for my principles, similar to the NAP?

          • albatross11 says:
            November 4, 2018 at 6:08 pm

            10240:

            Maybe I’m missing something, but it seems like this is too narrow. Suppose I formerly spent half my salary at the local bar (which was legal for me to do), and now I change my behavior to only spend 1/10 my salary at the local bar. Your formulation seems to say that this might be prohibited. (Not that it would, but that it might.) This seems like it locks in the current state of the world–once I’ve given my money to the beggar every day for a month, I am no longer allowed to stop because to stop would make him worse off.

          • 10240 says:
            November 4, 2018 at 11:44 pm

            Suppose I formerly spent half my salary at the local bar (which was legal for me to do), and now I change my behavior to only spend 1/10 my salary at the local bar.

            No because it’s legal to never spend any of your salary at the bar, and spending half of it up to a certain point and 1/10 after a certain point doesn’t leave the bar any worse off than never spending any of your money there, so it should be legal too. Same thing with giving money to the beggar and then stopping not leaving him worse off than never giving him any.

    • onyomi says:
      November 3, 2018 at 5:19 pm

      If I could recommend just one book on libertarianism to everyone it would be Michael Huemer’s Problem of Political Authority. The first half, especially, makes the best philosophical case I know.

      Socio-economically, I think it may be best summarized as a really strong emphasis on property rights, including individual property rights in one’s person (e. g. freedom to take drugs if you want, or not to be drafted). This is sometimes called “propertarianism.”

      • Telminha says:
        November 4, 2018 at 8:35 am

        Thanks!

    • sentientbeings says:
      November 3, 2018 at 7:50 pm

      I could write a lot about this, but I’ll try (edit: fail) to keep it brief.
      The first point is, it sometimes it’s easier to dip your toes in the water than jump in the deep end. Unfortunately, I don’t have advice for non-deep-end anymore beyond “learn about economics.” The first book I’d advise about economics (one suggested by people across political ideologies) would be Henry Hazlitt’s Economics in One Lesson.
      In learning about libertarianism, it might be helpful to direct one’s study based on how different people arrive at libertarian views. I’ll identify four ways below.
      (1) The accidental libertarian – basically, Gary Johnson. This category is the person who has this idea that people should be free and happens to endorse what are usually called socially liberal and economically conservative policies.
      (2) The deontological libertarian – the principled/rights-based view mostly dominated by Rothbard, but focused on the Non-Aggression Principle (NAP): Do not initiate violence on other humans.*
      (3) The consequentialist libertarian – David Friedman is the best resource for this one, and fortunately he happens to comment here quite frequently. The focus is heavily on polycentric law.**
      (4) The have-you-even-actually-thought-out-the-philosophical-justifications-for-the-state-because-they-pretty-much-suck libertarian – Philosopher Michael Huemer is the best (only?) authority in this category. Many of his arguments have been presented before in part by others, but IMO he does it in a sufficiently novel and rigorous way as to deserve his own category.***

      * Read For a New Liberty. I think Rothbard’s work is very good, but does tend to suffer form two major problems: (1) his discussion of legal systems implicitly assumes a central agreement that society wants libertarian law, so it’s not really a practical discussion, but an idealized one; (2) in some writing, he omits information that would damage his case.
      ** Read The Machinery of Freedom
      *** Read The Problem of Political Authority. It addresses the central issue of …political authority…, that is, how to justify the coercive state. It concludes that there isn’t a sound justification.

      As @toastengineer said, that the /r/goldandblack subreddit is a useful resource, but there is the problem of phrasing your inquiry in the right way. Many of the people who have the best knowledge to answer questions are also the most tired of answering them, so it’s important to differentiate yourself as someone with an honest inquiry rather than someone who is a troll, or lazy, or something else. If you want a good response, try tagging me (same username) or JobDestroyer in that subreddit.

      Another edit: If your goal is to “learn more about libertarianism,” some older historical works appreciated by libertarians might be useful. We are very fond of Lysander Spooner; consider The Unconstitutionality of Slavery and No Treason: The Constitution of No Authority.

      • Deiseach says:
        November 4, 2018 at 6:17 am

        how to justify the coercive state. It concludes that there isn’t a sound justification

        And since we’re not living in spherical cow land, where simply rebuking an errant person will have them going “Oh so sorry for intruding on your rights, I will amend my ways!”, then even a libertarian society or state will need some form of coercion – dress it up how they will – to cope with those who violate the principles.

        Since we don’t (yet) have a colony on Mars, the old solution of “simply move them on out – to Australia or the colonies or the West, anywhere away from the place they’re making trouble” is not going to work anymore. You get right of the bad apples in Westville, that only moves them on to Eastville, which may not appreciate you dumping your troublemakers on them.

        Even the “if you break your contracts, you will get a bad reputation” penalty envisioned by some libertarians is a form of social coercion that relies on everyone agreeing to shun the offenders or send them to Coventry. Have one person defecting on that, what is your means of dealing with defectors? Because human nature will remain, and you will have the person who is totally free to fuck himself up on heroin mugging you for money. Or simply living next door with all his junkie friends calling in to visit and the kind of environment that creates, and you going there to say “Hey how about you stop burning tyres in your back yard and maybe not have all these low-life skeezy types hanging around when my kids are coming home from school” is not going to do much on its own. What follows up when he continues with such behaviour?

        He gets evicted? The Residents’ Association determines that he’s broken the terms of living in the neighbourhood and he must leave? You call your private defence association to send round Mr Legbreaker to have a full and frank exchange of views with him?

        Some form of coercion is going to be in operation, whether it’s outsourced to the government or to a for-profit private business that you pay via fees or insurance premiums or otherwise. If your hired private security guards are behaving like cops and fulfilling the role of cops, then they are cops for all intents and purposes.

        • DavidFriedman says:
          November 4, 2018 at 10:34 am

          then even a libertarian society or state will need some form of coercion – dress it up how they will – to cope with those who violate the principles.

          I agree. In a libertarian society I can still use force against someone who tries to kill or rob me, and in a libertarian society sufficiently developed to have large scale division of labor I will probably arrange for someone else to use such force on my behalf. If you are curious about how such a system might work, I described it in some detail quite a long time ago and the second edition is webbed on my site.

          Even the “if you break your contracts, you will get a bad reputation” penalty envisioned by some libertarians is a form of social coercion that relies on everyone agreeing to shun the offenders or send them to Coventry. Have one person defecting on that, what is your means of dealing with defectors?

          Reputational enforcement doesn’t work that way. The reason I don’t hire someone after discovering that he cheated on his wife or defaulted on his debts isn’t that I am part of a conspiracy to punish him, it’s that the sort of person who does those things is not the sort of person I want to trust as an employee.

          I don’t think reputational enforcement is a complete substitute for the use of force, although there have been a few people who argued it was–one fairly well known fictional example of the argument is “And Then There Were None” by Eric Frank Russell. But it can, and in the real world does, substitute for a good deal of legal enforcement.

      • BBA says:
        November 4, 2018 at 7:10 am

        There used to be a very large fifth category of pseudo-libertarians, who were really into Ron Paul but only objected to enforcement of certain specific laws against certain specific people, and could be devastatingly authoritarian otherwise. Most of them splintered off into the alt-right once that became a thing.

        • sentientbeings says:
          November 4, 2018 at 12:31 pm

          It occurred to me this morning that I left off that group, but they receive a special asterisk. I call them “false-positive libertarians.” I think they don’t actually qualify as libertarians (pseudo-libertarian is a good term), though they do sometimes appear as members of the “group.” There are similar types that appear in other movements as well, and they are different from the accidental types in that they don’t find a sort of stable presence in the group – they are just passing through.

          They take different forms, but the alt-right folks you mentioned definitely qualify. For deontological libertarians, there is a potentially interesting discussion to be had in terms of what manner of response is justified once a person has suffered aggression. I believe that a moderately useful test for one “false-positive” group is that they use any NAP violation as a justification for extreme (i.e. deadly) responses. They also occasionally suggest that since the State is in a constant state of aggression, violent acts against government employees should be justifiable under the NAP. That sort of response is very much in conflict with a core goal that most long-term libertarians of all sorts tend to hold (often in a deep, personal way), which is the reduction of violent conflict.

          I hadn’t yet clearly formed my thoughts about this type at the time, but I had a related intuition that lead me to be harshly critical of a person named Christopher Cantwell several years ago. He was a divisive figure for a time and was eventually rejected by libertarians (to the point of being banned from anarchist events, which tend not to favor heavy-handed rules) as he went off the deep end. I think he is affiliated with the alt-right now, although I’m not sure.

          Another version of that group, probably more indicative of the once-Ron Paul-supporters than the alt-right per se, are just people who like the fringe. Thomas Massie (Republican United States Representative from Kentucky, one of the most libertarian members of Congress) has remarked that it dawned on him after Trump’s election that those were a large percentage of Ron Paul’s, Trump’s, and his, supporters. They want to vote for the craziest guy in the race.

          • HeelBearCub says:
            November 4, 2018 at 9:12 pm

            pseudo-libertarian is a good term

            This seems perilously close to a “No True Scotsman” argument. It strikes that given how many different ways there are slice the libertarian cake, you are going to start excluding huge chunks of self-identified libertarians.

            a core goal that most long-term libertarians of all sorts tend to hold, … is the reduction of violent conflict.

            People get in shooting matches about radios being too loud right now. It seems obvious to me that when you force neighbors to negotiate more and more of these types of issues, of greater and greater significance, the end result is more violent conflict.

          • sentientbeings says:
            November 4, 2018 at 9:57 pm

            @HeelBearCub

            This seems perilously close to a “No True Scotsman” argument.

            Be glad you said that to me online, and not in person. I don’t think people generally invoke that fallacy correctly, and I tend to discuss the matter at considerable length, causing a response not entirely dissimilar from the poetry of Prostetnic Vogon Jeltz. I’ll limit myself to saying that applying a test, even one that is incorrect, isn’t the same engaging in the fallacy.

            you are going to start excluding huge chunks of self-identified libertarians

            At somewhat of a tangent, self-identification is an interesting topic. I have read arguments that a person does not own one’s reputation that seem clearly correct. I have also read arguments along the same lines by at least two very smart people that claim one doesn’t decide his identity, but that it is determined by others. That does not seem wholly correct to me. I think that, with respect to group membership, there is an asymmetry in who determines membership that varies between inclusion or exclusion. That is to say, is seems to me that inclusion in a group is decided to a greater extent by other members or a definition or a test, while exclusion from a group is more in the hands of the individual. When a person states “I am not X,” I think that by default he deserves more credence than when he says “I am X.” That said, there is a reason that the national LP organization has new members sign a statement endorsing the NAP upon joining. I don’t think my guess-at-people-who-won’t-be-around-in-two-years test is too far off the mark., but it’s less of a precise test than a way to adjust one’s confidence.

            It seems obvious to me that when you force neighbors to negotiate more and more of these types of issues, of greater and greater significance

            I wouldn’t expect either of those – more negotiating or greater significance – to be true. Related to the former, I don’t see why neighbors would have to negotiate everything independently.
            We might think of the incentives in terms of millions of bilateral monopolistic negotiations, but that’s not what would actually happen. Related to the latter, I’ve seen more discussion lately of exactly the opposite – that increased political polarization is the result of a greater scope of human activity being determined in the political sphere. It seems much more likely to me that would result in violent conflict than private disagreements. It is much harder to effectively exit political disputes.

          • BBA says:
            November 4, 2018 at 10:22 pm

            My impression was that the pseudo-libertarians were a majority, or close to it, of self-identified libertarians back during the Ron Paul days. They’d talk about liberty but meant states’ rights – it was always the feds who were evil, states and localities got a pass, and there was a lot of opposition to the 17th Amendment which doesn’t have a damn thing to do with individual liberty.

            I also recall Paul endorsing a Constitution Party theocrat one year, and as a non-Christian I was not impressed. (And then there are those newsletters… but that’s a distraction.)

            I gave up on libertarianism pretty quickly when I realized the coherent, principled libertarian ideas weren’t going anywhere and the pseudo-libertarian ideas weren’t going anywhere I wanted to be. But that’s just me.

      • Telminha says:
        November 4, 2018 at 8:29 am

        I’ll make sure I understand a bit more before posting a question there. I added the suggestions to my reading list. I’ll start with the Machinery of Freedom. Thank you very much for taking the time to answer my question. I appreciate it.

      • arlie says:
        November 4, 2018 at 8:36 am

        Very interesting. I hadn’t been aware of the different reasons people became libertarian – particularly as leading to different varieties of libertarianism. When I first encountered libertarianism, it was in the form of a simple 2 axis graph which I can no longer easily find; it was basically a space for people who agreed with the left about personal freedom, but agreed with the right about something else – probably lack of business regulation, but presented in more positive terms. (At the time, it was quite persuasive; later experience changed my mind.)

        • Lambert says:
          November 4, 2018 at 9:59 am

          Nolan Chart and Political Compass, are two versions of that graph.
          Libertarians tend to frame lack of business regulation as ‘economic freedom’.

  4. smocc says:
    November 3, 2018 at 11:30 am

    I recently had an idea for a project where I try to write a life portrait of a distant ancestor based on whatever genealogical information I have, filled in with history-based speculation.

    I’ve selected an ancestor who lived near 16th century Bern, since that’s one of my longest known genealogical lines. Part of my work is now to find good Swiss history that I can read. I’m especially interested in daily life history. I’ve read good daily-life histories of England, but don’t know where to look for the same subject on Switzerland. Does anyone here have recommendations for where to start looking?

  5. johan_larson says:
    November 3, 2018 at 6:04 am

    Popular history tends to focus on some topics, to the detriment on others. There is, for example, no shortage of films and books and TV series dealing with Rome and Egypt, but there are very few dealing with Byzantium.

    With that in mind, what are the most over-studied and under-studied bits of history?

    For over-studied, I’ll take the Vikings. They ranged far and did some exciting things, but virtually nothing today bears a strong imprint of Viking culture.

    For under-studied, I’m going to take trade and economics. Popular history tells us a lot about rulers and wars and sometimes a bit about technology. It rarely says much about how people lived, what they grew and made and sold, and to whom.

    • dndnrsn says:
      November 3, 2018 at 7:15 am

      For popular history, what was going on just before major, disruptive events. There’s maybe been a shift away from this. It also depends what you define as “popular” – is a big doorstop book by a serious academic but meant for popular consumption popular history? I’ve seen more popular stuff that starts before the main event, so that’s something at least.

      For academic history, ironically, stuff that’s common in popular history. The style present in medieval-to-modern history back when I was in school, at least, was economic and social history. Military history was neglected, except insofar as it could be tied into social and economic history. Popular military history – where the hinge turned on Battle X and General Y – seems a bit gauche in academia? Problem is, sometimes the hinge does turn on Battle X and General Y. More generally, sometimes a single person is very important in how things went.

    • Hoopyfreud says:
      November 3, 2018 at 8:37 am

      Under-studied: the pre-columbian American Southwest!

      Maybe this is an artifact of where I went to school, but I have yet to find a good, accessible account of the Natives of the Southwest and Northern Mexico that matches either those dealing with the Aztecs, Maya, and Inca further south or the tribes the East coast settlers came into contact with.

    • Wrong Species says:
      November 3, 2018 at 1:33 pm

      People outside of China know nothing about Chinese history, even though it is often more bloody and bizarre than anything else.

      • cassander says:
        November 3, 2018 at 6:14 pm

        I didn’t have a really good answer for this question, but I think this has to be the right answer. greater China is a continent sized block with a lot of interesting history that isn’t read nearly enough. Do you have any recommended reading in chinese history?

        • Wrong Species says:
          November 4, 2018 at 7:06 am

          I don’t know a lot. I’ve been following the History of China podcast. I would definitely not recommend reading a single book that tries to outline all of Chinese history. I did that and retained nothing.

          • cassander says:
            November 4, 2018 at 7:45 am

            When it comes to history, I’m not a fan of the great courses because they’re too introductory for almost any subject they’re interested in, but they do have a good (I think) overview of chinese history that you might find helpful, From Yao to Mao: 5000 Years of Chinese History. But I’ll check out that podcast, thanks.

        • The original Mr. X says:
          November 5, 2018 at 4:37 am

          The Cambridge History of China is quite good: it covers the whole history of the place in one volume, so obviously it doesn’t go into great detail, but it’s still handy for getting a sense of the overall sweep of Chinese history.

    • Nornagest says:
      November 3, 2018 at 3:25 pm

      trade and economics. Popular history tells us a lot about rulers and wars and sometimes a bit about technology. It rarely says much about how people lived, what they grew and made and sold, and to whom.

      This might be popular vs. academic, or history vs. other historical fields. I took a field archaeology course in college and it was literally 100% digging up people’s trash and combing through it for clues about what they grew and ate and traded for. Pre-Columbian people, but still, trash.

    • bean says:
      November 5, 2018 at 6:10 am

      I’m going to limit myself to my specialty on this one.

      Over-studied, at least in popular accounts: USS Indianapolis. More than anything else, Indianapolis. Like, I get that it was a great tragedy when a cruiser got sunk, and the men spent a couple days swimming with sharks, mostly due to sloppy staff work. But when I have been to more than one library where the naval section had multiple books on Indianapolis and nothing that would have more than a page on Samar? Completely inexcusable. Shame on everyone who writes the books, and shame on those who keep buying them, particularly the librarians.

      Somewhat less overstudied in popular accounts: Anything to do with Bismarck (I make an exception for the new Garzke book). Midway. Maybe Pearl Harbor.

      Understudied: Samar and Leyte Gulf in general. Jutland. The naval battles off Guadalcanal. The US submarine campaign against Japan, at least these days. Jackie Fisher. WWI at sea in general.

      Really understudied: Mine warfare. Auxiliaries. The upper Solomons campaign and New Guinea. The importance of information-management techniques as opposed to guns and armor. Fire Control.

      Scholarly accounts are somewhat better-balanced, although I’ll put auxiliaries out as something that hasn’t been properly studied in a scholarly context, either.

  6. idontknow131647093 says:
    November 2, 2018 at 10:20 pm

    Today in media stepping on rakes (link to the twitter just so we dont give them clicks):

    https://twitter.com/VICE/status/1058092210544148481

    Essentially, a kid from Georgia moved to Tennessee for school and didn’t change his residence, car registration, or driver’s license. He then attempted to register to vote, but was denied because his situation clearly shows an inclination to maintain his domicile in Georgia rather than Tennessee. He goes on to call this voter suppression.

    Not only do several of Vice’s followers mock him for not understanding domicile law, he doesn’t even understand the depth of the self-own actually revealing in the article that, “Registering the vehicles in Tennessee would have incurred a pretty significant tax burden”. Meaning the whole article is really just about how a tax avoidance scheme meant someone had to vote in a state they didn’t want to.

      • idontknow131647093 says:
        November 2, 2018 at 10:09 pm

        I agree that WWIII would be an extremely unlikely path, but I kind of trust Hillary’s foreign policy instincts to consistently draw her towards bad ideas.

        On top of that I think its the realm where her, “you are just criticizing me because I am a woman” was most prevalent, most destructive, and most accepted by the media.

        The last part is really one of the biggest problems and why I think she might actually end up in a war in Crimea. She’d think acting tough was correct so she’d put ICBMs on the border and get drawn in, like an accidental Bush-2004 Iraq.

        • Nornagest says:
          November 2, 2018 at 10:19 pm

          She’d think acting tough was correct so she’d put ICBMs on the border and get drawn in, like an accidental Bush-2004 Iraq.

          Ballistic missile tech’s come a long way since 1963. There’s no longer any good reason for us (or for that matter Russia) to put strategic missiles on the border; we both have plenty of systems that can reach out and touch someone from the convenience of home, or the safety of an undisclosed location in the Pacific.

          A more likely, but still pretty stupid, scenario would involve deploying THAAD batteries or another ABM system to cover Ukraine or the Baltics. That wouldn’t be effective against ICBMs — we have precisely one system that is, it wouldn’t work with this geometry, and its effectiveness even in ideal conditions is debatable — but the Russians have historically seen deployments like that as a strategic threat anyway.

    • Conrad Honcho says:
      November 2, 2018 at 9:59 am

      I think it was still unlikely, but definitely more likely than Trump. She was threatening a no-fly zone in Syria. Who’s flying in Syria? Russia. So if she says “no planes over Syria” (who knows on what authority) and Putin says “nyet,” is she going to shoot down Russian planes? That could escalate, and there do seem to be aspects of our media and MIC that would very much like a conflict with Russia. I’m not sure who exactly would be there to tell her “maybe don’t get into a shooting war with Russia?”

      Regardless of how she may have handled North Korea, NK is incapable of starting WWIII.

    • Thomas Jørgensen says:
      November 2, 2018 at 10:04 am

      None whatsoever. He is committing the pan-glossian fallacy in spades.
      (That is, Trump is president, we are in the best of all possible worlds, therefore Hillary must have been a worse choice)
      Hillary was the candidate of the Status Quo, mostly, the one who did not want to burn it all down, but do some tinkering around the place to try and make things better without burning down the house. This very much includes on foreign policy. It is entirely possible a Hillary presidency would have included a war at some point, but it would have been a humanitarian intervention in some dusty country somewhere with no possibility of escalation, because Hillary was an extremely seasoned practitioner of state craft and would never have run any risks that contained any seeds of Armageddon.

      • Conrad Honcho says:
        November 2, 2018 at 10:37 am

        This seems like a scissor statement to me. The migrant crisis threatening the stability of all of Europe, the EU, and the existence of European liberal democracy itself can be traced to the brutal overthrow of Qaddafi, about which Hillary gleefully cackled, “We came, we saw, he died!”

        • dick says:
          November 2, 2018 at 11:23 am

          “extremely seasoned” is not necessarily a compliment. Hillary is an experienced mainstream establishment politician, and it’s really hard to imagine her doing something that would upset the apple cart, in either a good or bad way.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            November 2, 2018 at 12:25 pm

            But, I mean…the migrant crisis is bad, right? It could overwhelm and Islamify Europe over the coming decades, effectively ending Western Civilization.
